Award.AwardTitle: Climate change and environmental gender determination in a geographically-widespread species
Award.AbstractNarration:
The biological impacts of rapid changes in climate and habitats are major scientific and societal concerns. The need for clarifying these effects is particularly acute for species that are already imperiled. Turtles may be the most endangered group of vertebrates and, in the vast majority, temperatures experienced in the nest permanently determine offspring sex. This temperature-dependent sex determination (TSD) will be examined with a multi-year field, laboratory, and modeling study of wild populations of the painted turtle, Chrysemys picta, from climatically-divergent locations across the United States. This project will focus on measuring geographic variation in maternal nesting behavior and embryonic thermal sensitivity as potential mechanisms used by turtles with TSD to adapt to local climates. Teams of student researchers will conduct research at the field sites and in the laboratory each year. These activities will include monitoring behavior of nesting turtles, assessing incubating eggs and developing embryos, and recording environmental and habitat data. This information then will be incorporated into cutting-edge computer models to illuminate how changes in local climate will affect nest temperature and thus offspring sex ratio. In turn, the model predictions will be tested experimentally to identify how populations with TSD must adjust behaviorally and/or physiologically to offset any imbalance induced by thermal alterations.

These integrated studies should provide a comprehensive understanding of how species with thermally-sensitive traits might adjust to forecast scenarios of rapid changes in climate and habitats. The findings will be particularly germane to conservation of species with TSD. This multi-year program also will (1) build a broadly applicable tool for translating between temperature measurements at point sources (nests, plant roots, etc.) to thermal variation at the habitat level and then to regional climate, (2) improve understanding of the scientific method by enhancing a lesson plan for 5th-grade students, and (3) continue to provide first-hand scientific and educational opportunities for numerous students (including underrepresented minorities, persons with disabilities, and women).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many species have to deal with considerable variation in temperature throughout their geographic range. Ectothermic organisms, such as reptiles, are particularly sensitive to this thermal variation because temperature influences nearly all of their functions. How these organisms deal with different thermal conditions across broad geographic areas and how they might cope with climate change are two major questions in ecology and evolutionary biology. To address these questions, we studied the painted turtle, which has a peculiar form of sex determination that depends on temperature. Under temperature-dependent sex determination (TSD), the sex of offspring is determined permanently by temperatures that embryos experience in their nests during development. In addition, given that the painted turtle has a broad geographic expanse (east to west coasts of the U.S. and from Mexico to Canada), this species is an excellent model for examining how organisms deal with such a broad range of environmental conditions in terms of a critical trait (i.e., sex) that is influenced by temperature. Specifically, we predicted that this species copes with considerable thermal variation via 1) physiological shifts in sensitivity of sex determination to temperature across climatically different locations, 2) behavioral shifts in maternal choice of nesting habitat in ways that affect temperatures inside nests, or 3) a combination of both mechanisms. Overall, our research examined how this widespread species currently accommodates geographic variation in climatic temperatures from physiological and behavioral perspectives.

By studying turtle populations at seven widely-distributed locations (Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Mexico, Idaho, Oregon), our research provided evidence of local adaptation. On the physiological side, although the temperature that produces a balanced offspring sex ratio was generally similar across the painted turtle’s range, the sensitivity of sex determination (i.e., the slope of the relationship between temperature and sex ratio) was relatively low at more southern study locations. This finding suggests some physiological adaptation to dealing with differences in thermal environments among our study locations. We also demonstrated that females nest non-randomly with respect to canopy cover at all study locations (except for one). For example, females chose nest sites that were more open than available, which, in turn, elevated typical nest temperatures by several degrees during embryonic development. Notably, this non-random nesting behavior was more pronounced in more northern study locations. This behavior could compensate for the relatively cooler ambient conditions at northern latitudes, and facilitate production of balanced offspring sex ratios.

Beyond focusing on biological responses to different climates in a globally-endangered group of vertebrates, this project supported substantive outreach, as well as sponsored many high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. The primary outreach activity involved development and delivery of 5th-grade lesson plans focused on science education. The lesson plans infused many aspects of our field research to illustrate the iterative process of science (scientific method) and key associated concepts (e.g., bar graphs) via critical thinking and teamwork, which required the students to improve mathematical and communication skills. Our research project also engaged numerous more-advanced students – the majority of them members of underrepresented groups in science – in a diversity of scholarly projects related to the main research objectives. These research/education experiences fostered critical thinking and teamwork, which is necessary for the students’ success in careers in the life sciences and elsewhere. Indeed, many of our undergraduate participants already have advanced to graduate/professional programs in the sciences or education where they continue to utilize the skills they obtained while working on this research project.
